results.title: [Tony Agapitos: First Greek Community Dance at Exhibition Centre 1961]
results.brief_description:
This film shows the first Greek Community Dance held at the Royal Exhibition Buildings, Melbourne in 1961.

The film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Arrival of the Greek Ship "Patris" at Victoria Dock 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows the arrival of the Greek ship ‘Patris’ to Victoria Dock in 1961 and her passengers coming to Australia to start a new life.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: Victoria: 100 years of progress
results.brief_description:
This documentary looks in detail at the history and development of Melbourne, using artist’s sketches and filmed footage to depict the history of Melbourne. Some items include the Manchester Unity Building, cars of the era travelling down St Kilda Road, St Kilda Beach, a brief history of the Princes Bridge, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Geelong and industries and transport existing in 1934. Also includes footage of the opening of Parliament.

Includes archival footage of early transport-cars; shipping; rail (Flinders Street Station); Prince’s Bridge; St. Kilda Beach; Anzac Parade; Flemington Race Course. Arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York for the first opening of Federal Parliament 1901. Also featured: scenes of the city: Collins and Swanston Streets; Melbourne Town Hill; The Exhibition Building; Parliament House and large private homes in the suburb of Toorak. Reference is made to agricultural and pastoral industries - wheat; wool production; fruit growing and tanning in Mildura. Three masted sailing vessels plus a farewell for the ocean liner Strathnaver. Finally, a re-enactment of gold mining/panning and heralding the first one hundredth birthday of the settlement of Melbourne
[SOURCE: NFSA Collection catalogue)

results.title: Assault on the Land
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
Examines the problems of salinity, showing how it affects not only the farmers, but all of us. Several methods currently in use to combat the problems are examined in areas of Victoria.

results.title: [New Zealand Weekly Review. No. 201]
results.brief_description: Newreel items include: 1. UNRRA. Clothes for Europe, loading stores for refugees in Europe. 2. Hastings - Spring show. 3. Temuka - Bailey Bridge in Civvies. Wartime Bailey Bridge erected to help country area. 4. From war to peace - returned servicemen train for the building industry. 5. McKenzie Country - down from the tops.

results.title: Lifeblood of the city
results.creator_credit: Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
results.brief_description: How Melbourne has always depended on the Yarra for its existence. The expanding city has drawn upon the Yarra and its tributaries, culminating in the development of the head-waters of the Yarra itself. The climax is the building of the Upper Yarra Dam, shown in detail. The film uses old prints to illustrate past development of Melbourne, with emphasis on its water supply. Material filmed at all stages of the ten years of building the Upper Yarra Dam presents a full picture of how a large rock and earth dam is built. Concludes witht he opening of the reservoir by Sir Dallas Brookes (26th November 1957). Commentary by Geoff Raymond.

results.title: Davis Cup, 1956
results.creator_credit: Peter Whitchurch and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
results.brief_description: Edited action footage of all the matches in the 1956 David Cup Final between Australia and USA. Australia won all matches to make it its 13th Davis Cup victory and was represented by Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall and USA by Victor Seixas, Herbert Flam and Sam Giammalva. Contains footage of historical interest including Robert Menzies in various spectator shots, Harry Hopman receiving Davis cup from Richard Nixon, then Vice President, for 1955 victory.

results.title: The Davis Cup, 1951
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s fight to retain the world tennis premiership. The film covers the Interzone Final in Melbourne between Sweden and the USA and the Challenge Round in Sydney between the USA and Australia. Narrated by Michael Charlton and Peter Whitchurch.

results.title: By Lake and Stream
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: An account of the work being done to maintain the trout population of Victorian lakes and streams. Shows the initial trapping of adult fish, stripping of eggs from the female fish, and subsequent hatching of young fry at the Snob’s Creek hatchery, keeping the young fish in brooding ponds, and finally the release of the trout to replenish lakes and streams. Various trout fishing techniques are demonstrated, and the film concludes with scenes of anglers in action in many parts of the State.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this home movie, we see footage of Wirth’s Circus, including acrobats, trained elephants and horses, and trapeze artists, followed by footage of Luna Park in Melbourne.

The film then travels to Adelaide, meeting the arrival of ‘The Overland’ train from Melbourne, followed by visits to Torrens Lake, Koala Bear Park and Torrens Gorge.

The final section of the film shows the ANZAC March in Melbourne (1938) and a family road trip to Sassafras in the Dandenongs.
